titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Renata Vickrey

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-08-10

did.unittitle: Stanislaw E. Bask-Mostwin collection
did.abstract: Stanislaw Edward Bask Mostwin was an achieved war hero and political activist in his lifetime. He was awarded several military decorations during WWII and after immigrating to the United States became actively involved in Polish and Polish American causes. He belonged to groups such as the Polish National Democratic Committee, Polish Heritage Society in Maryland, Polish American Congress, and North American Study Center for Polish Affairs (STUDIUM). The collection includes papers from these groups, especially STUDIUM, and other essays and writings on the state of Poland at the time and its history.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Stanislaw Edward Bask Mostwin was a lawyer, engineer, Polish Army officer, and a political activist in various Polish American organizations. Mr. Mostwin was born in Poznan, Poland in 1917, where he attended the Poznan University School of Law. In 1945 he graduated with a law degree from Warsaw Underground University School of Law. He attended The Officers Cavalry School in Grudziadz. After WWII he attended engineering training in England and George Washington University School of Law in Washington DC.

Stanislaw Mostwin took active part in military operations in September of 1939. He was wounded and awarded Virtuti Militari, the highest military decoration for heroism and courage. He escaped from Poland in 1940 via Palestine and enlisted with the Polish Carpathian Brigade under British command. He participated in the North African campaign where he was wounded and awarded the Virtuti Militari for the second time. In 1943 he was sent to England where he participated in training for the Special Forces and completed training for the British Intelligence. In 1944 he became a special emissary of the Polish government-in-exile and traveled to Poland. He parachuted behind Polish lines in May of 1944. He participated in the Warsaw Uprising and cooperated with the Polish Underground. In 1945 he married Danuta Pietruszewska (who became an author and sociologist) in Warsaw. In December of the same year, facing arrest by the secret police, he escaped with his family to England.

In England, under auspices of the Polish Resettlement Corps, he completed engineering training and in 1951 immigrated to the U.S. with his wife and son. He settled in Baltimore where he worked at several textile companies as an engineer and designer. He also attended George Washington University Law School.

Mr. Mostwin and his wife Danuta were very active in working on behalf of their homeland. Mr. Mostwin was an active member of the Polish National Democratic Committee in Washington, a co-founder of the Polish Heritage Society of Maryland, and national director of the Polish American Congress. In 1975 he was a co-founder and later vice-president of the North American Study Center for Polish Affairs (STUDIUM), an academic think tank that examined Polish political affairs from the U.S. perspective.

He was a strong advocate for the Polish-Jewish dialogue. He was a chairman of the STUDIUM Committee on Polish-Jewish dialogue and established the Janusz Korczak Literary Award for children's literature. Janusz Korczak was an assimilated Polish Jew, working as a children's writer, educator, and pediatrician. His real name was Henryk Goldszmit. Before the war he established an orphanage for Jewish children. During WWII the orphanage was moved inside the Warsaw Ghetto and in August of 1942 all were sent to Treblinka and put to death. Korczak received many offers to be smuggled outside the ghetto but he did not want to abandon his children.

In the 1990's Mostwin worked on further dialogues with other ethnic groups and organized a conference between Polish Americans and German Americans in Washington, DC. In 1980's he was involved in gathering congressional and financial support for Solidarity in Poland and after Martial Law was established he was involved in getting support for the Solidarity support groups organized in the US. Mr. Mostwin wrote many analytical essays on Poland's independence and Polish-Jewish relations. In recent years his activism diminished. He died on May 30, 2011 at the age of 94.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of material related to the establishment and activities of STUDIUM from 1975 until the mid 1990's, documented by correspondence, minutes, membership, treasurer reports, publications and position papers. It includes articles and historical essays on the history of Poland, economy, and current political situation in Poland the Eastern bloc. It also includes records of the Polish American Congress and records of other organizations of which Mr. Mostwin was a member.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials note
separatedmaterial.p: Serial publications were removed and added to our circulating serial collection.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Cite as: Stanislaw Bask-Mostwin collection (CPAA 94-01). Connecticut Polish American Archives, Central Connecticut State University, New Britain.
